titlestmt.titleproper: Finding Aid for the Allan Manings Papers PASC.0138

address.addressline: Room A1713, Charles E. Young Research Library

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on 2022-09-07 13:01:29 -0700.

did.unittitle: Allan Manings papers
did.abstract: Allan Manings was a television comedy writer and producer who created the situation comedy One Day at a Time with his late wife, actress Whitney Blake. The collection consists of script materials related to Manings' career. Notably absent from the collection are materials related to One Day at a Time.
did.physloc: Stored off-site. All requests to access special collections material must be made in advance using the request button located on this page.

accessrestrict.head: Restrictions on Access
accessrestrict.p: Open for research. All requests to access special collections materials must be made in advance using the request button located on this page.

userestrict.head: Restrictions on Use and Reproduction
userestrict.p: Property rights to the physical objects belong to UCLA Library Special Collections. All other rights, including copyright, are retained by the creators and their heirs. It is the responsibility of the researcher to determine who holds the copyright and pursue the copyright owner or his or her heir for permission to publish where The UC Regents do not hold the copyright.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: [Identification of item], Allan Manings Papers (Collection PASC 138). UCLA Library Special Collections, Charles E. Young Research Library, University of California, Los Angeles.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: Collections are processed to a variety of levels depending on the work necessary to make them usable, their perceived user interest and research value, availability of staff and resources, and competing priorities. Library Special Collections provides a standard level of preservation and access for all collections and, when time and resources permit, conducts more intensive processing. These materials have been arranged and described according to national and local standards and best practices.
Processed by UCLA Arts Library Performing Arts Special Collections staff, pre-1999.

We are committed to providing ethical, inclusive, and anti-racist description of the materials we steward, and to remediating existing description of our materials that contains language that may be offensive or cause harm. We invite you to submit feedback about how our collections are described, and how they could be described more accurately, by filling out the form located on our website: Report Potentially Offensive Description in Library Special Collections.

odd.head: UCLA Catalog Record ID
odd.p: UCLA Catalog Record ID: 9922211203606533

bioghist.head: Biography/History
bioghist.p: Allan Manings was born in Newark on March 28, 1924, and grew up on Staten Island. He served in the Pacific during World War II and was in the first group of men to enroll at Sarah Lawrence College, in 1946, as part of the G.I. Bill. During the McCarthy era, Manings moved to Canada until the early 1960s. He wrote scripts for shows like Leave It to Beaver and Rowan and Martin's Laugh-In; he won an Emmy for his work on Laugh-In. Manings and his wife, the actress Whitney Blake developed the television series One Day at a Time for Norman Lear's production company. He was a former board member and vice president of the Writers Guild of America West. Allan Manings died on May 12 in Los Angeles, CA.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: The collection consists of materials related to television comedy writer and producer Allan Manings. Included are script materials for Amanda's and Bustin Loose, among others. Notably absent from the collections are materials related to the television series One Day at a Time.

arrangement.head: Organization and Arrangement
arrangement.p: The collection is arranged alphabetically by program titles.

controlaccess.subject: Television comedy writers -- United States -- Archives.
